abstract.p: The frames that Lewis Carroll provided for the two Alice books have largely been ignored, when not simply dismissed, in recent Carroll criticism. Their conventional form and diction may account for this negative response, but examination of their provenance, their function within the structure of the two books, and the artistry evident in the individual frame components indicate how and why the frames are important to our understanding of Carroll's vision and purpose. The frame poems are designed to lead the reader into and away from the central dream tales through a process of lyric transformation and estrangement.

Paul Ricoeur's words, to "bring the hero or heroine back into a primordial space and time that is more akin to the realm of dreams than to the sphere of action. Thanks to this preliminary disorientation, the linear chain of time is broken and the tale as- sumes an oneiric dimension that is more or less preserved along- side the heroic dimension of the quest" (181). 181
Carroll was working within the Romantic mode, us- ing the lyric present to memorialize an ecstatic experience and effect in the reader the "quality of estrangement" (570). 570
Schachtel 320 320
Schachtel 286-87 286

K. Mellor observes: "Alice's sister's definition of 'dull reality' is as arbitrary and fractured as Carroll's description of Wonder- land. The description of the 'real world' is a sentimental pastoral idyll culled from literary tradition. . . . As such, it is as much a denial of the chaos of noumenal becoming as is Wonderland" (173). 173

Carroll undercuts the pastoral idiom, presenting the phenomenal world of the farmyard scene as a tame ("dull") surface manifestation of the noumenal chaos ("clamour") that the dream expresses. The passage twice asserts the older sister's awareness ("she knew . . . she knew") that this seemingly innocuous "reality" will inevitably and all too soon reemerge; the return is presented as a loss, a return to everyday blindness and unawareness (98-99). 98
Carroll's comments show that the second book grew out of the first (Letters 1: 94, 124). 94
her the Under Ground manuscript in November 1864Under Ground 1864

Carroll's term love-gift as perhaps the most adequate definition of fairy tale that we have (27). 27
His analysis of Thousand and One Nights (86-92)

Carroll reverses the position of two of the narrators in the chain (Alice and the Red King), further challenging the reader's as- sumption that he is on the very outside of the box-the last one in a line of listeners-rather than part of the story being told to yet someone else. (99) 99

his iambic lines mechanically rendering the endless repetitive processes of na- ture evokes a world as meaninglessly circular as the story that follows is meaninglessly linear, breaking off in midair with a "but-" (166-68). 166
Virginia Woolf's characterization of Alice as heartless and ruthless (82) 82

Elizabeth Bowen: "As children, we wanted knowledge. Growing up, we have found ourselves fobbed off with information. We have the answers, but have forgotten the questions. It is, probably, that delight of the search, that sense of enigma, that urge toward exploration, which a skillful book about childhood does most to revive." Alvin C. Kibel perceptively analyzes Alice's "decent humility of spirit" relative to an ideal of courtesy that he sees, rightly I believe, as a sign of intellectual and moral strength (623). 623
